title: U.S. Service-Sector Activity Picked Up in August
text:
The U.S. service sector expanded for its 115th straight month in August. A Starbucks in Burbank, Calif.

WASHINGTON—U.S. service-sector activity in August grew more quickly than in July, according to the Institute for Supply Management’s nonmanufacturing index released Thursday.

The report, based on a survey of purchasing managers, provides a sense of business conditions for the country’s service providers, which include businesses like restaurants, banks and consulting firms.

Here are some key takeaways: •The ISM’s nonmanufacturing purchasing managers index rose to 56.4 in August from 53.7 in July. Economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal had expected the index to increase slightly to 53.8. A reading above 50 indicates expansion, while a reading below that level indicates contraction. •According to the ISM, the service sector has expanded for 115 straight months as of August—a contrast compared with the manufacturing sector, which shrank for the first time in three years last month. •Employment growth in service industries softened in August from the month prior, according to the ISM report. Nonetheless, August represents the 66th consecutive month of growth in service-sector employment. •Business activity and new orders accelerated in August after cooling in July.
